title: 109_hr4915
content: The Act is titled the "Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States Reform Act". It clarifies the review and investigation process. Section 721 of the Defense Production Act of 1950 is amended to include a National Security Review process for proposed mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers by foreign entities that could result in foreign control of U.S. businesses engaged in interstate commerce. The President or their designee will review these transactions to assess potential national security implications. The Defense Production Act of 1950 is amended to include a National Security Review process for foreign mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers that could result in foreign control of U.S. businesses. The review process requires consideration of specific factors and a response to each factor's applicability. If a foreign government or entity could control a U.S. business, the transaction is treated as potentially having national security implications. The National Security Review process under the Defense Production Act of 1950 considers foreign mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers that could result in foreign control of U.S. businesses. Any agreement establishing conditions to mitigate national security risks requires approval from the President or the Secretary of the Treasury. The National Security Review process under the Defense Production Act of 1950 evaluates foreign mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers that may impact U.S. national security. If a review indicates potential national security concerns, an investigation is conducted by the President or their designee to assess the effects on national security. The National Security Review process evaluates foreign mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers for potential impact on U.S. national security. The President or designee establishes procedures for investigations analyzing factors listed in subsection (f) to address concerns raised by the transaction. The National Security Review process evaluates foreign mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers for potential impact on U.S. national security. Procedures are established to investigate and address concerns raised by the transaction, including setting time frames, considering the impact on the open investment policy, and providing guidance to the designee conducting the investigation. The designee will report investigation results and recommendations to the President for consideration. Investigations must be completed within 45 days of determining potential national security impact. SEC. 3. AUTHORITY TO TAKE CERTAIN ACTIONS AFTER WITHDRAWAL OF NOTICE. Section 721 of the Defense Production Act of 1950 is amended to include provisions for interim protections in case of withdrawal of notice for a proposed merger, acquisition, or takeover before completion of any review or investigation. The Defense Production Act of 1950 is amended to include provisions for interim protections in case of withdrawal of notice for a proposed merger, acquisition, or takeover before completion of any review or investigation, including specific timeframes and tracking processes for resubmitting notices. SEC. 4. ADDITIONAL FACTORS REQUIRED TO BE CONSIDERED. Section 721(f) of the Defense Production Act of 1950 is amended to include new factors for consideration in transactions, such as the impact on critical infrastructure, involvement of foreign government entities, and other factors determined appropriate by the President or designee. Increased oversight by Congress is emphasized in Section 5. Section 721 of the Defense Production Act of 1950 is amended to include new subsections requiring an annual report to Congress on reviews and investigations related to mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers for national security concerns. The amended Section 721 of the Defense Production Act of 1950 requires an annual report to Congress on reviews and investigations related to mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers for national security concerns. The report must include details on concerns raised, how they were mitigated, and the status of the transaction at the end of the year. Additionally, a quarterly report on transactions under consideration must be transmitted to Congress every calendar quarter. The amended Section 721 of the Defense Production Act of 1950 requires an annual report to Congress on reviews and investigations related to mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers for national security concerns. The report must include details on concerns raised, how they were mitigated, and the status of the transaction at the end of the year. Additionally, a quarterly report on transactions under consideration must be transmitted to Congress every calendar quarter, containing necessary information about the nature, scope, parties involved, and potential mitigation agreements. The Defense Production Act of 1950 has been amended to require an annual report to Congress on reviews and investigations related to mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers for national security concerns. Additionally, a quarterly report on transactions under consideration must be transmitted to Congress every calendar quarter. Section 721 of the Defense Production Act of 1950 is amended to establish the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States as a multi-agency committee with specific members designated by the President. The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States is a multi-agency committee with specific members designated by the President, including the Secretary of State, Attorney General, Secretary of Homeland Security, Chairman of the Council of Economic Advisors, United States Trade Representative, Director of the Office of Management and Budget, Director of the National Economic Council, Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy, Director of National Intelligence, and other designees from the Executive Office of the President. The Secretary of the Treasury serves as the Chairperson of the Committee. The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States involves heads of other Federal agencies in investigations as deemed appropriate. Meetings are held as directed by the President or the Chairperson. The Committee may conduct hearings, receive evidence, and subpoena witnesses. The Committee may issue subpoenas for witnesses and documents as determined advisable by the Chairperson or the President. Subpoenas can be issued and served by the Chairperson or a designated member of the Committee. The Committee has the authority to issue subpoenas for witnesses and documents. Failure to comply with a subpoena may result in a court order for testimony or evidence production, with contempt of court consequences for non-compliance.
